assessment.instructions: Reach one hand over the top of your shoulder and down your back. Simultaneously reach the other hand behind your back and up. Try to touch your fingertips together. Measure the gap (or overlap) and then switch sides to compare.
assessment.what_it_reveals: A gap larger than two inches — or a significant difference between sides — indicates restricted shoulder rotation. The tight side often points to the rotator cuff or lat that's driving the pain.
assessment.cta: If your hands can't meet — or one side is noticeably tighter — the shoulder mobility drills in today's video address those exact restrictions.

strategy_json.theme_narrative: This week 'shoulder pain' is trending across search, social, and health forums. Based on the data we collected, this is a high-opportunity topic for Bart's audience of desk workers, athletes, and chronic-pain patients.

ai_findability_tips: Use Q&A format: 'What causes shoulder pain?' with a direct answer paragraph so LLMs and featured snippets can extract it
Include structured data (HowTo + FAQPage schema) for search engines and AI crawlers
Write definitive statements LLMs can quote as authoritative — e.g. 'The most effective exercise for shoulder pain is...'

engagement_replies.suggested_reply: Great question. From my clinical experience with shoulder pain, the most common mistake I see is jumping straight to stretching without addressing the underlying movement pattern. Try starting with Band pull-aparts — it targets the root cause rather than just the symptom.
